title: 113_hr3018
content: The Gun Violence Prevention and Safe Communities Act of 2013 is also known as the "Gun Violence Prevention and Safe Communities Act." It includes an increase in excise taxes related to firearms under Section 4181 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Gun Violence Prevention and Safe Communities Act imposes taxes on the sale of firearms, pistols, revolvers, lower frames or receivers, shells, and cartridges at specified percentages. The Act also includes an exemption for sales to the United States. The Gun Violence Prevention and Safe Communities Act imposes taxes on firearms, lower frames, shells, and cartridges purchased with funds appropriated for any department of the United States. Funds from increased taxes are allocated for community-oriented policing services grants. The Gun Violence Prevention and Safe Communities Act allocates funds for school resource officers to improve school safety and promote positive reform in student discipline. 35 percent of the funds are available for Project Safe Neighborhoods, while 10 percent is allocated for other purposes. The Gun Violence Prevention and Safe Communities Act allocates funds for various programs: 10% for research on gun violence prevention, 5% for criminal history improvement, 5% for NICS Act Record Improvement Program, and 5% for Community-Based Violence Prevention Field-Initiated Research and Evaluation. The Department of Justice allocates 5% of funds for the Secretary of Education to provide grants and assistance to schools for implementing evidence-based strategies to improve school climate and reduce exclusionary discipline. The Pittman-Robertson Wildlife Restoration Act is amended to exclude a portion of the tax related to the Gun Violence Prevention and Safe Communities Act of 2013. The amendments apply to sales after December 31, 2013. SEC. 3. SPECIAL TAX AND LICENSING RELATING TO FIREARMS. Increase in Tax under Section 5801 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with amendments for general rule, small importers and manufacturers, and adjustment for inflation. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust for inflation in taxable years after 2014, increasing the dollar amount in subsection (a)(1) based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Additionally, the transfer tax on firearms is increased from $200 to $500 under section 5811 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The transfer tax on firearms is increased from $200 to $500, and the tax on ammunition is increased from $5 to $100. Inflation adjustments will be made for taxable years after 2014 based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The transfer tax on firearms and ammunition is increased, with adjustments for inflation. Certain semiautomatic pistols chambered for rifle rounds will be treated as firearms. Effective dates for the amendments are specified. Effective December 31, 2013, the transfer tax on firearms and ammunition is increased. Taxpayers starting a business on July 1, 2014, subject to an occupational tax will be treated as commencing business on that date.
